description: From Middle English admonesten, admonissen, from Old French amonester (modern French admonester), from an unattested Late Latin or Vulgar Latin *admonestrāre, from Latin admoneō (“remind, warn”), from ad + moneō (“warn, advise”). See premonition.

verbs.description: admonish (third-person singular simple present admonishes, present participle admonishing, simple past and past participle admonished)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To inform or notify of a fault; to rebuke gently or kindly, but seriously; to tell off.
examples: Synonyms: reprimand, chide; see also Thesaurus:reprehend

entries.meaning: (transitive, with of or against) To advise against wrongdoing; to caution; to warn against danger or an offense.
